G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, and **G.L. c. 215, § 6**, as the original decree was entered in this Court and the minor children reside within Bristol County.

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The proposition is a bare "see also" citation to Adoption of Hugo without specifying any legal principle. A generic see-also signal only requires that the case be relevant to the broader topic, here adoption/best-interests analysis, which this opinion clearly is. Because the case is a leading Massachusetts decision on best interests, competing adoption plans, and judicial discretion in DSS-sponsored adoptions, it appropriately functions as a see-also reference.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The “best interests of a child” is a question that presents the trial judge “with a classic example of a discretionary decision.” Adoption of a Minor (No. 2), 367 Mass. 684, 688 (1975).

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: These circumstances materially affect the children’s stability, safety, and routines, and constitute a substantial change warranting modification pursuant to **Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, § 28**, and as interpreted by *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), which holds that a parent seeking to modify custody must demonstrate a material and substantial change and that modification is in the best interests of the children.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a custody‑modification standard case under § 28. The decision discusses the ‘best interests of the child’ in the context of showing “cause” for removal when parents share joint physical custody, but it does not articulate or apply the § 28 standard that a party seeking custody modification must first prove a material and substantial change in circumstances. The proposition attributes to Mason a § 28 “material and substantial change” requirement that appears only in the quoted ALI Principles passage and not as a holding of the court, so the citation overstates what Mason decides.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents…shall not…be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth…without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, the Court may modify custody and parenting orders upon a showing of a "material and substantial change of circumstances" and when modification serves the children's best interests.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Massachusetts law requires that parenting schedules serve the **best interests of the children** (*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states that under G.L. c. 208, § 30, ‘upon cause shown’ means that removal must be in the best interests of the child and repeatedly characterizes the court’s task as determining the children’s best interests. In explaining the removal standard, the court emphasizes that although the custodial parent’s interests are considered, the children’s best interests remain the paramount concern, confirming that parenting/custody determinations must serve the best interests of the children under Massachusetts law.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent…’”}

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts law requires that parenting schedules serve the **best interests of the children** (*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses the ‘best interests of the child’ standard as the governing principle in Massachusetts custody determinations, citing Yannas and other cases, and applies that standard to the parenting schedule and custody allocation in this case. The court also confirms that G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) requires custody awards for nonmarital children to be made according to the child’s best interests, with statutory factors guiding but not replacing that standard. This directly supports the proposition that Massachusetts law requires parenting schedules to serve the best interests of the children.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., … Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Modification to restrict overnight parenting time to nights when the Defendant is off work aligns with the guiding principles of *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001) (parenting plans must adapt to changed circumstances to protect the child’s best interests), and *Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000) (court must balance parental rights against the paramount concern for the child’s wellbeing).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: Rosenthal v. Maney concerns when a change in custody is warranted and how courts should analyze a custodial parent’s request to relocate, emphasizing the need for a material and substantial change in circumstances and a best-interests analysis in that context. It does not address, endorse, or discuss modifications that restrict or structure overnight parenting time around a parent’s work schedule. While it refers generally to the child’s best interests and changed circumstances, using it as specific authority for limiting overnights to nights when a parent is off work overstates and mischaracterizes its holding.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ … ‘The uprooting of a child … should be done only for compelling reasons.’”

Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).proposition: Modification to restrict overnight parenting time to nights when the Defendant is off work aligns with the guiding principles of *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001) (parenting plans must adapt to changed circumstances to protect the child’s best interests), and *Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000) (court must balance parental rights against the paramount concern for the child’s wellbeing).
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).support_reasoning: Williams v. Massa is primarily a property division, alimony, and custody case. On custody, the only legal principle it clearly articulates is that changes in custody must be sought via a complaint for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28, not by motion; it does not discuss modifying parenting-time schedules in response to a parent’s work hours, nor does it set out any balancing test for parental rights versus the child’s best interests in the way the proposition suggests. The opinion therefore does not provide authority for tailoring overnight parenting time to a parent’s work schedule as described in the proposition.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996) — custody determined by child’s best interests, considering family stability.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is primarily about requiring explicit findings on the impact of domestic violence in custody determinations, but it does so within the established Massachusetts framework that custody is decided based on the child’s best interests. The court emphasizes that domestic violence and its effects on the child must be expressly considered in deciding custody, which fits within the broader ‘best interests’ analysis, though the opinion does not specifically highlight ‘family stability’ as a separate factor. Thus it supports the general best-interests principle with a focus on safety from family violence rather than stability in the abstract.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: "The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the child. . . . [A]buse of any family member affects other family members and must be considered in determining the best interests of the child in connection with any order concerning custody. . . . Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking."

Verts v. Verts, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 81 (20.raw_text: Verts v. Verts, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 81 (2003)
Verts v. Verts, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 81 (20.proposition: *Verts v. Verts*, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 81 (2003) — courts may modify parenting schedule to prevent instability caused by parental unavailability.
Verts v. Verts, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 81 (20.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal/probation revocation case about operating a motor vehicle with a suspended license and related due process issues in probation surrender proceedings. It does not concern family law, custody, or parenting schedules, nor does it discuss modifying any parenting plan due to parental unavailability or instability. Therefore, citing this case for authority on modifying parenting schedules is inaccurate and unsupported by its holding or reasoning.
Verts v. Verts, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 81 (20.relevant_excerpt: "The defendant appeals from the revocation of his probation, based on evidence that he was operating a motor vehicle under a suspended license... Probation had been imposed... after the defendant admitted to sufficient facts to warrant a finding of guilty on a charge of operating a motor vehicle under a suspended license... On these facts, the defendant raises several issues implicating due process; we find no merit to his contentions and we affirm the revocation decision."

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012) — joint custody viable only when both parents can cooperate in providing care.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses legal and physical custody under the best interests of the child standard and notes that a parent’s willingness to support the child’s relationship with the other parent is an important factor. It does not state or hold that joint custody is only viable when both parents can cooperate in providing care as a categorical rule. Rather, the case affirms an award of joint legal custody and primary physical custody based on multiple best-interest factors, including but not limited to cooperation, so it does not clearly establish the claimed proposition.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: "The judge found that disrupting the attachment a child has to a parent and behaving in ways designed to alienate a child from that parent causes harm that can be long term, and if sole physical custody must be awarded because of geographic distance between parents, ‘it is in the best interests of a child to be in the sole custody of the parent who can support the involvement of both parents rather than with the parent who alienates the child from the other parent.’"

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981) — material change justified modification where prior schedule became impracticable.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with standards for initial custody determinations and the requirement that the judge base custody on the child’s welfare and make appropriate findings. It does not address modification of an existing custodial schedule, material change in circumstances, or impracticability of a prior schedule. Thus it does not support the proposition that a material change justified modification where a prior schedule became impracticable.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981) — modification appropriate to align with children’s developmental needs.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on initial custody and visitation determinations in the divorce judgment, applying the general ‘best interests of the children’ standard and analyzing whether joint custody is appropriate in light of parental conflict. It does not discuss modification of an existing custody or support order in response to children’s changing or developmental needs, nor does it articulate any standard about modifying orders to align with children’s developmental stages. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific modification proposition stated.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the children] should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the children] in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future, and it is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.”

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.raw_text: Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981)
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.proposition: *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981) — a shift in parental availability supports change in custody or visitation schedule.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with removal of children from the Commonwealth and the impact on visitation, but it does not discuss a ‘shift in parental availability’ as a basis for changing custody or a visitation schedule. Instead, it holds that in deciding a custodial parent’s relocation request, the court must consider the well-being of the custodial parent and possible alternative visitation arrangements, rather than treating the increased difficulty of visitation as dispositive. Thus it is about relocation/best-interests analysis, not about modifying custody/visitation due to a change in a parent’s availability.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.relevant_excerpt: “From what we can ascertain, the judge recognized the importance of the ‘frequent and continuing contact’ of the child with both its parents… and entered his judgment prohibiting removal on the basis that the move would make visitation more difficult. We consider that factor not in itself conclusive. The best interests of children for purposes of deciding whether to permit removal are also interwoven with the well being of the custodial parent… He did not discuss the possibility of alternate visiting schedules which would preserve and foster the important relationship of the children with their father.”
